Zitarrosa Jan 29 2011
+23 Vote downBookmarkVote up
What could I say about Pepper's that haven't been said yet? Yes, it embraced several different music genres (oftenly in the course of the same song). Yes, it turned rock music into a recognized form of art. It started the idea of using the studio as in instrument and changed pop music. Those are all clichés, but remain true year after year, as naming Albert Einstein the most important scientist of the XXth century or The Godfather II the greatest movie ever made. Some clichés remain for a reason and the reason is: Pepper's is always in the top 10 of every single "best album list". It doesn't matter if voters are critics, musicians or just ordinary people. It's always there. Some argue it didn't age well and it's not surprising and fresh new as it was in 1967. In fact, this album may be outdated and stuck in the summer of love, but "A Day in the Life" is walking in the opposite direction: From just another fine Beatles' song (it was behind of "She's Leaving Home" in the day upon it's release) to the XXth century Magnum opus (side by side with Dylan's "Like a Rolling Stone" or The Who's "Baba O'riley").

Kevvy Jun 10 2005
+37 Vote downBookmarkVote up
If I am to review Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band based on the assumptions (or convictions) that the album is out-dated, over-rated, over-hyped, or over-anything, then I am sadly entering a tired old debate that I want nothing to do with.

We all know the story of The Beatles. Hell, when ever I read over just one of their many Bios, I get goosebumps and the uncontrollable urge to get down and funky with all things Beatles. The one and only stumbling block I can't get around on my path to Beatles fandom, is their music.

True, I wasn't alive in the 1960s during the Beatlemania-mania that I've read so much about, so I don't have the luxury of nostalgia when I pop something like Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band into my stereo. I'm not by any means implying that nostalgia is the only reason that so many folk rant and rave over the Beatles, I'm just saying that sometime nostalgia helps.

I'm of the belief that good music remains good music for its entire lifetime, not just for one period of time. When I listen to Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, I hear some of the absolute worst pop songs I've ever forced myself to become familiar with. "With A Little Help from My Friends," "Within You Without You" (even though I do enjoy George Harrison, this song baffles me), "Lovely Rita," and the unforgivably cheesy "When I'm Sixty-Four" (hey, I have a sense of humour, but that much cheese is overpowering) make me question why the Beatles ever deserved so many accolaids for this album.

Yes, I know one of my heroes, Otis Redding, loved this album to bits, but I can't pull anything really likable off of it other than the title track and "Getting Better." What could Otis see that I can't? There are probably millions of Beatles fans in the world that are even younger than me, so I doubt I 'had to be there' when it happened, so what gives?

The obvious jabs like "if you don't like The Beatles, you don't like music," or "you hate melodies" come up whenever it is revealed that I'm not a Beatles supporter. Listen, I dig Motown and r&b and pop and rock n roll as much as the next person. Give me a well crafted Smokey Robinson ballad or a gut-bustin' Marvin Gaye tune any day of the week and I'll lap it up completely.

I love pop music, so why don't I love the Beatles? Their popularity isn't discouraging me, since Motown had more number one hits than pretty much anyone else. So what is it? To me, it comes down (again) to the music. None of these songs click with me. Even my all-time favourite Beatles song, "Daytripper," sounds better coming from Otis Redding.

I guess I'm going to have to accept that there are hundreds of better bands out there (in my mind) than The Beatles. I don't take delight in not liking them, nor do I look down on their fans. I'd love to be a member of the Beatles fan club, but the music on Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band is nothing special to me.

Epilogue:

As a result of my review and rating of this album, it was suggested to me numerous times that I "re-evaluate" my copy of Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band. The world has a billion Beatles fans and I don't see what the big emergency that I'm not one is, but I did what I was told. I waited until I really was in a calm and lazy mood and I put Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band in my CD player. My mood couldn't have gotten more annoyed. The title track has such a dopey chorus that it ruins the intensity of the rest of the song. "Getting Better" seems to get chunkier as the days go buy, I wonder why I used to like it? "Lucy In The Sky With Diamonds" has some of the worst metaphors in pop music, and there are some bad ones out there. Man, I could rant on and on but what's the point. I'm not a Beatles hater, but there's nothing I really like anymore about this album. My "re-evaluation" of Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band resulted in a lower rating.
Published
drakkar Jan 25 2020
+2 Vote downBookmarkVote up
We all know The Beatles' early works, the 'Ticket to Rides' and 'I Want to Hold Your Hands' of the world. All that silly old stuff. We all remember the coming of age with Rubber Soul and Revolver.

Then came Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, and even those following the band didn't see it coming. They'd gone and blown a hole through the bloody roof. It certainly wasn't their best collection in my opinion with too many songs that didn't fully measure up (the title track, "With a Little Help From My Friends", "When I'm Sixty-Four", "Lovely Rita"), but it is perhaps the most-ambitious rock album ever made up to that point and shook up pretty much everything in the realm of rock music for the rest of eternity (we won't discuss the cheesy movie at this venture, eh?).

And the Paul Is Dead clues run rampant as well. I mean, the hand over his head? Facing backwards on the back cover? The flower bass? 'He die'? 'He blew his mind out in a car'? 'O.P.D'? You know that's right. And dang it, The Beatles are on the cover twice, and then they were even hidden on Their Satanic Majesties Request. What more proof do you need? And then the whole concept of that oft-emulated cover. Ackaphobia! Somebody once told me that i was in there, but i haven't found myself yet. I keep looking.

In any case, if i'm just judging this as 13 songs ignoring the ambition and creativity of the release as a whole, then outside of a couple 20-star bombs, this is really a collection of 2-star, maybe 3-star tracks. But the total is truly greater than the sum of its parts.

 djiaind Dec 21 2014
+9 Vote downBookmarkVote up
If the ratings were out of 10, I might give it a 9.5. There have been moments since its release, when I have grown tired of some of the tracks. That it has never strayed far from best-selling, and all-time favourite, album lists, so long after its June 1967 release, is mainly due to the album's energy and general maintenance of quality throughout. Made when The Beatles had stopped touring, but were still eagerly composing and preparing great music in the recording studio, gives it a very special quality. Pepper was the first of the tragically few albums that bear witness to the immense but short-lived artistic fuse of the band as they were finally able to concentrate on playing & recording great music in the confines of a studio rather than on the frenzied gigs.

"A Day in the Life" has become, for many of the band's musical fans, one of their all-time favourite tracks. The title track still sounds good, and still produced a significant audience response, when covered by McCartney on his most recent tours. "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds", "Within You Without You" (George Harrison's great offering), and "She's Leaving Home", all great pop/rock classics, remain among their best ever songs.

The Beatles were also often humorous critics of the society that made them entertainment icons. "Lovely Rita" and "Fixing a Hole", particularly the latter, are everyday life odes, almost in the perceptive mould of The Kinks' or The Small Faces'.

It is not my own personal favourite, but it is certainly one of the best records that the Beatles ever made and one of the first albums that someone collecting their work will want to have. Even if it did not represent the 1967 Summer of Love as well as its Californian counterparts, it was undoubtedly the best album of Rock Music's most important summer.

Overall Rating: 5.00

Outstanding Tracks: Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds; Within You Without You; With a Little Help From My Friends; She's Leaving Home & the masterpiece, A Day in the Life

OtherBarry May 24 2013 ▼
+17 Vote downBookmarkVote up

I HAVE OPINIONS!

01) This is not the best Beatles album, though it is at the very least in their top 3.

02) The album will stand forever as a testament to what can happen when a handful of musicians with otherworldly talent and vision work together in harmony and with purpose. Oh, and drugs. Lots and lots of drugs.

03) John Lennon might be an asshole, but I couldn't care less.

04) "Lovely Rita" is one of the most underrated tracks in The Beatles' discography. Absolutely wonderful song.

05) There are very few true examples of a 'timeless' album, especially considering the amount of qualifiers such a suggestion brings in to question. This is one of them.

06) If this album is at any point legitimately considered the best album of all time by a majority of music fans, I will be content.

07) George Harrison is awesome.

08) Haters gonna hate.

09) Seriously, I've been consistently baffled by some of the opinions I've heard about Sgt. Pepper's over the last few years. Especially on RYM. Especially when they involved such vague concepts as 'hipsters', 'overrated' or 'pretentious'. Baffled because, even though I'm certainly a massive fan of this album (and of this band), I never recognize myself in the stereotypical figure usually regarded as the 'average Beatles fan'. Also, because I see these same users hype bands that are just as 'pretentious', 'overrated', and 'hipster-friendly' (The Velvet Underground, Radiohead, Animal Collective, Arcade Fire, Kanye West, etc.)

10) In all honesty, there's only two legitimate reasons I can see why anyone would find this album utterly repellent: "Within You Without You" and "When I'm Sixty-Four" which are both bad songs. Everything else here is just a bliss and simply cannot be denied. But then I also don't like consensus so ultimately I'm completely fine with haters, as long as they have sound arguments (see point 09 for counterexamples).

11) While the album doesn't mean a lot to me, or hold any sort of sentiment, I will continue to defend it's greatness until I die. There are a lot of albums out there that deserve backlash, but Sgt. Pepper's simply isn't one of them.

12) Luv ya, marsbars, KelidescopeBeamz, and anyone else who hates this album. May Paul McCartney have mercy on your wretched souls before he sentences you to an eternity of nothing but Ringo Starr solo albums.

*All rights reserved to SinsofArcadia and flyingwill. Hopefully, neither will take any legal action.

Some consider this album "dated". Well, of course it isn't, but if you aren't into the music of 1967, then you may skip this.

Anyway, to me this remains the best of their output. The songs may have been stronger on "Revolver" but this works better as a whole.

And a few words about influence. This album may not sound very influential today, but that is because of stuff that happened 10 years later. In the wake of punk, suddenly musical skills, ambitions and sophistication was seen as something negative, not positive like before. "Sgt. Pepper" _did_ however influence a lot of great music before that. Without "Sgt. Pepper", there would have been no Genesis, no Yes, no 10cc, no ELO. Lots of GREAT bands that made great and clever music that would have deserved way more praise than what did happen in the wake of punk (and later hip-hop). Thus, "Sgt. Pepper" did get to influence some of the best music ever made before good music because unfashionable and bad music got trendy.

pianoporsche Apr 07 2013 ▼  
+4 Vote downBookmarkVote up
  • A1 Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band
  • A2 With a Little Help From My Friends
  • A3 Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds
  • A4 Getting Better
  • A5 Fixing a Hole
  • A6 She's Leaving Home
  • A7 Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!
  • B1 Within You Without You
  • B2 When I'm Sixty-Four
  • B3 Lovely Rita
  • B4 Good Morning Good Morning
  • B5 Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (Reprise)
  • B6 A Day in the Life
I'm still adjusting to the fact that I like this for all the "wrong" reasons. "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds"? Clumsy, lumbering chorus. "Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite"? A tepid, gussied-up circus tune. On the other hand, I'll defend "Lovely Rita" (drum clatter, acoustic scrape, panicky outro), "Good Morning Good Morning" (fuzzy horn blasts), and the titular reprise (punchy guitar/drum salvos) 'til I die.

Adding to my heresy against The Greatest Album of All Time, I find its concept laughably nonexistent, barring the bookending medleys. Now normally, aside from chuckling at critical wet dreams, I wouldn't care about something like conceptual integrity. Then again, when the release and its surrounding discourse get hernias from persuasive effort, I get irritated when the music doesn't match the arguments. Honestly, the only cohesion I find here lies in how stilted some of these rhythms are. Notwithstanding Paul's bohemianism, "Fixing a Hole" is about as limber as a thumbtack and nowhere near as sharp.

To reassure you: Yes, I enjoy this album. The opener is as playful, grand, and inviting as the rest of the LP tries to be, and Ringo's fills on the immortal closer are testament to his subtle brilliance. But the more superlatives I hear thrown Pepper's way, the harder my knee jerks, amplifying (seemingly) small annoyances into major points of contention. (Is the laughter at "Within You Without You"'s end necessary? It makes the spirituality seem insincere--something I'm sure George didn't intend.)

Removed from its reputation, Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band is a solid, if inconsistent, set of tunes that fails to reach its loftiest intentions. With neighboring releases more sonically interesting and less maddeningly forced, it's hard for me to see where the cheerleaders are coming from. It's an album I enjoy less with each successive listen, one that encourages my worst reactions to The Fabs, and a shameless attempt to hop on a hippie scene far more interesting. (People who hold this as some psychedelic masterpiece confuse and enrage me.)

So, once again, this album does have some dazzling moments. And the advances in recording technology are undeniable. But in the rush to crown the group Best In Class, too many are too willing to overlook its faults--a disservice to any artist, let alone one so highly praised. And if it takes a piece as crabby and cynical as this one to help counterbalance the froth, so be it.

Besides, fans get to call me a Beatles-hater and I get to continue jamming out to "Lovely Rita". It's a win-win.
Published

Rules for comments
  • Be respectful! All the community rules apply here.
  • Keep your comments focused on the release. Don't post randomness/off-topic comments. Jokes are fine, but don't post tactless/inappropriate ones.
  • Don't get in arguments with people here, or start long discussions. Use the boards for extended discussion.
  • Don't use this space to complain about the average rating, chart position, genre voting, others' reviews or ratings, or errors on the page.
  • Don't comment just to troll/provoke. Likewise, don't respond to trollish comments; just report them and ignore them.
  • Any spoilers should be placed in spoiler tags as such: [spoiler](spoiler goes here)[/spoiler]
Note: Unlike reviews, comments are considered temporary and may be deleted/purged without notice.
